content:
23, 2014
												Risen is an action role playing game in which you the player are pitted against the horrifying enemy of the game's controls and interface. The majority of the game's problems stem from the poorly handled camera. Locked in third person perspective, the camera is drawn as an evironment object. This results in the camera catching on terrain geometry and causing all sorts of havoc with movement and combat. One minute you may be facing an opponent and the next a wall, as you back through a doorway or past a column. The combat system is exceptionally poor. When facing an enemy, the camera snaps to target (a "feature" with no way to disable it). This doesn't work even with a single target, as mobs will frequently run around you, the snap breaks as you turn to follow, or the mobs dodge through your character due to some sort of bug or allowance for model collision strictly for mobs to do so. This turns fighting multiple opponents into a nightmare of camera jerks, lost targets, easy flanks and hits by the enemy against you. Apart from the camera, the combat itself is frustrating and poorly implemented. In Risen, combat is handled through Attack, Parry, and Block functions via the left and right button only. Yes, parry and block are tied into the same mouse button and vary only by press vs click. This, with the slow interface, results in an awkward jumbled dance of trying to time your parry against enemy attacks (when they can be parried) and trying to maintain blocking (against enemy attacks which can't be parried). This combined with the variance in mob attack speeds (from slow as hell to instant) results in you either missing your parry (while knowing the enemy is going to attack) and getting hit because your character is too slow to (this is due to canned animations) or parrying wildly against nothing because you misjudged when a mob was actually going to swing.Fortunately this combat can almost entirely be disregarded as ranged combat weapons and kiting are the most effective form of combat, provided you have the space to manuever and weapons powerful enough to harm your opponents. Unfortunately, ammunation is scarce and will result in you running between vendors hoping to find more ammo. Fortunately mobs on the island only respawn when certain plot progression triggers are met, meaning you can clear the entirety of the game out in due course. This is of course a poor attempt and lengthining the game artificially, as you will be required to clear out areas once again as new quests become available, making it far longer than it should be.This brings up another issue, the canned animations. Risen gleefully provides an animation for every single action you can do in the game world. Want to see what's in that cupboard? Your character will walk over to it and open each door (one at a time if you happen to be holding a torch, which is actually kind of impressive that they thought to do that), after which he will close the cupboard, one door at a time. No containers are allowed to be left open in this game, with the exception of actual building doors for some reason (I guess the islanders aren't big on privacy). This applies to every usable object and action in the game world. Your character will be locked into the animation until it is completed. This creates numerous frustrating moments when your character is caught looting in combat as he takes hit after hit while slowly closing the top of the chest he happens to be sifting through. It also provides moments of absurdity should you shoot your crossbow and hit jump while in the reloading animation. After reloading the weapon your character will immediately jump, after the 5 second reloading animation has run its course, preventing you from firing your now reloaded crossbow. You can also be stun locked off of ledges, resulting in you falling to your death if you are unfortunate, or to take heavy damage if you are not.In the same vein, the game possesses numerous geometry issues with terrain and player model interaction. On more than one occasion, I found myself stuck in a falling animation as my character bumped into a slight incline in the terrain geometry, enough that it was considered a "step" while also being tall enough to be considered a "fall". Fortunately you will know when this happens as your speakers will issue forth a cacaphony of juddering impact sounds (akin to the classic Half-Life crate/barrel collision noise).It should be noted that there were numerous problems between nagivating traps and the use of the various "magic spells" the game offers. Frequently, the use of a spell which turns your character into a tiny critter, would result in your untimely demise when reaching the otherside of a spike trap, though you are perfectly safe standing still between the spikes. As if the designers deliberatly set up a killzone on the otherside if you did not navigate it the way they desired you to. Strange considering you can just jump across some of them without being hurt.I almost forgot to mention that the spells themselves are all consumables requiring you to find more copies of that spell to use or to craft, which also requires consumables and specific recipies and their component materials. Some of these materials were not even available until half way through the game (nor was the ability to craft them either). Crafting (apart from making consumables) was an utter waste of time. There was no craftable armor, and the half dozen rings and swords you could make, were instantly outmoded when progressing the plot. It seems exceptionally odd to include prospecting, 3 prospectible materials, when all you can make is the same 4-5 swords. Accessory crafting relied heavily on what gems you've found, and generally only rarely provided an upgrade in equipment.On a positive note, all of the game's voiceover dialogue is entirely spoken and you won't find yourself reading walls of text (unlike this review). The voice acting is well done though character animations are sloppy and the dialogue itself is the basic cliche grim-dark fantasy stereotype.Character animations are fairly decent though tend to take on a comical exaggeration for certain actions.The astetic fits the narrative with some exceptions and is in keeping with the setting.The graphics are godawful for a game that was released in 2009. This was the year we had games like Grand Theft Auto 4, LA Noire, Fear 2, and Modern Warfare 2. These graphics looked like something out of 2003. The textures and meshes were passable, but some of the models were distinctly lacking in polygons.The plot is the most standard generic dark fantasy tripe that anyone ever shoveled out of a Penguin Book's publication, invovling the destruction of the Gods, the return of the Old Ones, and the awakening of the Titans. Boring, generic, hero's quest garbage where you the lone hero must overcome incalcuable odds and save the world from the most bad who is trying to gain the great power, despite spending half the game working with him to get access to it. Your intrique and "choices" are limited to, join the bandits, or join the inquisition (why there is an inquisition I have no frigging clue as they killed all their gods anyway and I didn't see anyone worshiping them). In the end nothing really important happens, the status quo is maintained, and the rest of humanity is apparently left to fend for themselves in the wake of on going giant monster attacks.Don't even bother with this game. If it comes in some kind of bundle I reccomend giving it away, particularly to someone you hate as it is more akin to torture than it is any semblance of fun. You should know what to expect from a studio like Piranha Bytes if you've played a game of Gothic 1-3. Risen is the same ♥♥♥♥ wearing a different shirt.Gameplay: 1/10Graphics: 5/10Sound: 8/10Plot: 5/10Length: 5/10Overall: 6/10

												2016 Review:Graphics: 7Music: 7Fun: 7Value: 7Risen is a 3rd person POV RPG/adventure game. Focus is on combat and exploration. You are given choices in the story to choose what type of character you will develop, depending on the faction you choose. You can be a warrior type, mage or a hybrid of the two.  I found the story to be decent. Exploration was rewarding. Combat is pretty difficult, especially at the start. Getting 1 or 2 shotted by enemies is pretty common. You'll have to study your enemies to figure out their movements and time your attacks and blocks exactly right. As the game goes on, combat gets easier as you gain better armor, range weapons/magic and your attacks grow stronger.  There are some puzzles, but none that are too obtuse. All-in-all I found this to be a good game and worth your money, especially with some of the discounts going on where you might be able to pick up a pack Risen 1-3 games for a big discount.

												Not a terrible game, but not quite good enough to get a recommendation. Game takes place on a small island, with only 1 real town in it. You spend the entirety of the game going between 3-4 little outposts areas and going in dungeons, so it doesn't feel very epic or varied. In classic pirhanna bytes fashion, the game is buggy with clunky mechanics. Theres a bug where you can't climb ledges without disappearing and having to restart, and this happens every time you try and climb, making it a gamebreaking bug. You have to go specifically to your video card settings in your control panel to change it. The combat is awful. There's dodging and attacking and blocking, but it is pretty terrible. You never know when enemies are going to attack. The worst is, while youre hitting them and damaging, they can suddenly shake off being hit and start blocking, parry you, or even worse....somehow attack betweem your combo and start hitting you. But if they do that, you're never able to attack during their combo. Sometimes you can block during, but many times they can keep hitting you. This terrible unpredictable system that benefits enemies causes you to only hit once or twice because you can't trust combos. The parry system doesn't work, and trying to do it just gets you hurt, causing you choose to just block instead. The dodging only works sometimes, others even when you dodge you still somehow get hurt. The quest system is terrible. There's no markers, no clean indication of where to find qhich questions, and when you go to the quest in your log, there is no objective listed or even the most recent directions given by the person. There is a lot of quests to do, and multiple choices and different options, different factions, and some questions cancelling out others, which is nice. The leveling system is terrible. Gaining a level gives you 0 stats or abilities. You then need to find the specific trainer to not only train stats, but also abilities. It also costs money. And some trainers you need to do quests before they train you, meaning you can lose out on abilities if you didn't make the right choices. I never got a chance to use many magic spells because i never found the exact trainer for them, which is stupid, or I didn't have enough GOLD to get stat points. The armor systems stinks too. I never found helmet armor until the like 10-15 hours in, only found  3 chest pieces in 20 hours, and a few different rings. That was the boring system. The game is long though, and has a lot to do.In the end, the bugs, the terrible combat, the bad inventory, the small world, and the awful quest system all cause this game to be below par, which is normal for these developers. Not a terrible game though. 6/10.

content:
, 2014
												First of all - I am a huge Gothic fan. I like the first two installments of the series (along with the Night of the Raven). I couldn't get over Gothic 3, Forsaken Gods and Arcania - they simply broke my heart.Now, please, turn on this track before you start reading this review. I insist:


YouTube™ Video: Gothic 2 Soundtrack - 20 Monastery 

			Views: 14,459		

			Titel: Monastery Artist: Kai Rosenkranz Game: Gothic 2		

Turned on? Okay, you're good to go.Risen isn't a perfect game, but it's good enough for me. I'm enchanted with Gothic, of course, but that's a legitimate reason for me to like Risen. The game has many references to Gothic (familiar character names, bandit camp in the swamps, Harbor City, civil war, an isolated island with tense residents - it just makes you feel like in the two original Gothic games).What can I say about graphics... I'm not someone who is familiar with the newest graphics. I played Metal Gear Solid 5: Ground Zeroes and I can admit that the graphics there are astonishingly beautiful. What about Risen? They're... different than that. That's all I can say. I just lost track and can't really tell a difference. I guess it might be safe to say that this game's graphics have aged somehow, but they aren't bad even for today's standards.The audio is lacking in something - particularly Kai Rosenkranz's music (EDIT: actually, I just found out that Kai *did* compose Risen's OST - but it is different for some reason, so different that I couldn't even tell this was Kai's music indeed). This is the thing I miss the most. Kai really had a talent to create great, varying moods throughout the entire games with mere music. Once you feel at ease, at another time you feel tense, and at totally another time you feel grave. I would dare to call him one of the best composers, I would even dare to say he's better than Soule. Risen lacks this atmospheric music, unfortunately. It changes your mood subtly, but it simply isn't as powerful as it was in Gothic. Still, it has some catchy tracks, but you just can't really remember where they play after you turn the game off. Gothic didn't have that problem at all. If you did as I asked you to do - turned the Monastery track from Gothic II, it should have ended at this point. If it didn't, you probably have heard a large portion of it, or at least it started to loop. You can finish listening to the track, or simply stop it. Your choice. However you decide to do, please, turn this track on right now. I insist:


YouTube™ Video: Monastery - Risen OST 

			Views: 1,445		

			Music from Risen game audio files Composed by Kai Rosenkratz		

The difference is obvious.The gameplay is the most important aspect to criticize here. And here's the trouble. I cannot be unbiased. Like I said, I treasure Gothic dearly, and this game *is* like Gothic. You have many references to it (or just self-repeating patterns because of the developers' laziness - but it doesn't bother me, I like it). If you played Gothic, you'd have no trouble figuring Risen out, no walkthroughs needed at all. But if you're new to PB's games, then I suspect this game will be a challenge to you.The island is small (about the same size as Khorinis). But it is extremely detailed. I couldn't find any broken places with floating trees, rocks or other, similar stuff (hi, Todd*). The world is semi-open - just like in Gothic. It doesn't feel like you're crawling through dungeons and linear pathways. Of course, that means the world isn't randomly generated on the spot by the game, and everything is pre-defined, which can be either a pro or a con, depending on the perspective (this makes this game's replay value lower, I guess).The fighting system reminds me of Gothic - you can't just click mindlessly, but time your clicks and have a tactical approach to fights. If you are stupid, you can be level 15 and get beaten by a pack of wolves. But if you're smart, you can defeat a tough, armored guy equipped with a decent sword when you are a fresh castaway. Your combat ability depends mostly on your skill as a player, not on your characters' stats. Of course, even the best players will probably lose against some opponents if the odds are impossible enough.It is a specific game. Not for everyone. But still, is any game suited for everyone?All in all, if you are a fan of first two Gothic games - do get it. I'm sure you won't regret it. If not - get a demo and try it. Or simply ignore it. Maybe it'll appeal to you, maybe not. You will have to try it out yourself.My personal rating: 8/10.(*Todd Howard, CEO of Bethesda Softworks, famous mostly because of The Elder Scrolls series and Fallout 3 and New Vegas)

 OVERALL: 4/10 ===Pros & Cons + Pros + + Good level of interaction with NPCs+ Choices you make in the Storyline will drastically change where you end up and what quests you do+ Good stealth mechanics - Cons - - Combat system is completely broken (there will be a special section down in the review where i will explain this in detail)- Miserable variety of equipment and loot- Character leveling system and development are aswell completely broken (details later)- The class you develop is bond to certain questlines you may or may not follow (details down aswell)- Miserable graphics even for the year it came out- Interaction with the game world is non-existent- Characters are anonymous, uninteresting and inexpressive. It looks like talking to (badly) animated tree stumps.=== Special Section - About Gameplay, Combat System and Character Progression This is an extraordinaire section i made just for THIS review, in which i will explain to you, esteemed reader, the abyssal flaws i have described up above.1. Combat System: Risen's combat system, regarding melee mostly, is such a mess i have rarely witnessed in my whole gaming career. First of all, attack patterns, movement animations, speed, parry system are wholly flawed beyond repair. Enemies can dodge your attacks which is fine, but they can aswell attack just after they dodged, in the span of a tenth of a second, which you cannot do at all, and then repeat their attack animation a random number of times consecutively, this can very certainly end up with your character being 1-shotted by an unstoppable series of attacks you cannot parry, for there is a little delay between when you are wounded and when you can again parry; this delay is larger than the delay between the enemy attacks, so you cannot do any action while under a barrage of attacks.Secondly, facing multiple enemies is totally unfeasible: you can focus your attention on just one direction while attacking, your attacks are bond to follow that direction as long as the animation goes on. This means, you cannot, say, hit one enemy with a slash then hit another one near him and then a third one. Attacking one enemy leaves you totally exposed from all other directions, from which enemy can attack you like i described before. Player cannot even lure single enemies, as triggering combat with one will very likely trigger the whole enemy field and drag you to a multiple combat you have zero chances to win, unless said enemies are very far below your level.Third, animations are clunky, unresponsive and generally really messy. Players will have trouble timing attacks and also to spot when an enemy is going to attack, since there is no pre-attack animations, nothing, enemies just stand there then attack instantly without any little notice, and then return to their idle animation.2. Character Development: Oh boy here we go. first of all your class is bond to the storyline you might want to follow: for example if you choose to be a bandit, you will not be able to be a mage. This because when you level up, this game has no normal RPG style level up system, but instead gives you Learning Points, and nothing else. These points can be used at specific trainers around the world to improve your Statistics or Abilities. Fact is, certain branches of the Main Quest will allow you only to learn certain classes' skills as i said before. This limits the experience a player may want to pursue heavily. Also, trainers cost Gold, each ability you learn costs gold, and also Statistics cost gold, other than Learning Points.This system is totally failed and limits the developmetn of your character by a lot.=== Final Thoughts Risen could be a nice game with its setting and storyline, but many gameplay-breaking issues and bad art direction flaw this game beyond salvation.I do not recommend this game at all, unless you just want a world of pain and suffering.

												The melee combat system is incredibly bad and possibly the worst I have ever had the displeasure of suffering through, but that's only the tip of the iceburg.Enemies will block any time you're attacking and wait for a split second where they can attack, dealing 1/4 to 1/2 of your health in a single attack because you have no access to armor until you go through a long series of quests that involve fighting said enemies, said enemies can also chain attacks.And even if I had somehow managed to get armor I have my suspicions that it wouldn't have done much for protection until I got really really good armor.You're given the option to either continuously attacking and hope you catch them in that split second they decide to stop blocking, or you get behind them, which of course barely works.Enemies turn on a dime to track you, the only conceivable way to get behind them is by dodging, which of course also barely works as you will go straight in whatever direction you dodged, and enemies recover quickly so if you don't do it perfectly you'll never get behind them.Enemy and player blocking can be lowered by having two characters attack at once, but from my frustrating experience you're always alone, and enemies are often in numbers, so if you're not fighting them in a hall with no room for them to move about, you're going to get hit with a chain of attacks because your blocking is meaningless.Another frustrating experience is that though you're not guaranteed to be killed, even the so-called friendly NPCs who you train with will rob you blind if you lose a fight.I have heard many good things about Risen which is why I bought this game, but from my experience it seems very little thought and testing was put into the combat, and I'll said it again, this is possibly the worst melee combat system I have ever had the displeasure of suffering through.

er 14, 2014
												I'm a fan of RPGs of any age but Risen, unfortuantely, has to go on my 'no fun to play' list. I had hopes going in it'd be fun, given it has a different style to classic action-RPG mechanics but most of these differences were very frustrating because the game itself does an EXTREMELY poor job of, at least, making you aware of the changes. Did not make for a good start for a Let's Play series on YouTube.The graphics and audio have aged well, though the characters are pretty bland and uninteresting for the most part... but I admit I haven't gotten far in the game. The lack of presence of the story also does not encourage me to keep playing. Without a solid anchor to the narrative, I can't really immerse myself into the game. For games like Skyrim, it works well because they hook you into the story within the first couple of hours but Risen just doesn't get the hooks and alludes to no concept of the story you're suppose to be experience in the first part. You're just some dude who got ship-wrecked and, for some reason, has to pick a side without knowing what the hell is really going on. (Which I am aware you find out later)Most of the controls I had to learn through trial and error, since the tutorial parts are either bugged or just stop after teaching you how to open your inventory, looking at the character screen, and how to swing your weapon. Things like blocking and parrying are fairly easy to figure out but dodging took some effort as well as how to upgrade my stats, since leveling up doesn't seem to affect them at all, which would have been nice to be made aware of at the start and I still don't think I understand the whole system revolving stats aside from blowing gold on trainers... who seemed rather expensive in the early stages.Then there's armor... probably my biggest issue with the game. The fact I didn't find a piece of armor at all but I was practically tripping over weapons was quite confusing. I honestly thought I had broken the game or was just being an idiot (I like to think I'm semi-good at video games, especially RPGs) but when I researched several walkthroughs on the game, it became very clear you can only recieve armor under particular circumstances or paying a lot of gold if you manage to find a vendor that's got a set so... that was a huge 'NO' in my book. Not asking to have everything I kill drop items like a pinata but there should have been as many options on armor availability as there were weapons. Gathering the gold was an unneccessary and annoying side track that ate into time I could have spent progressing the story... but then some of the enemies towards finishing up joining The Don were barely survivable unless you have impeccable block/parrying skills (which I did not).Though I, personally, would not recommend this game to anyone and have much more confidence in other RPGs from the same time that would be enjoyable... I'd say give it a shot if you're interested and draw your own conclusion. I just found this title to be no fun and that does not give me hopes for its two sequels.

content:
er 2, 2015
												For the first 24 hours or so of playing this game, I was sure that I'd be giving it a positive review if for no other reason than because I had spent nearly all of my free time playing it since I started. By the end of it the best thing I can say about it is that I'm still interested in trying Risen 2.The tone of the first half and the second half of the game is alarmingly different. From when you first wash up on the beach with a fellow castaway who proves entirely irrelevant to the point where the main plot is actually explained to you, the game spends its time impressing upon you how much of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ the island you arrived at is and how the population is the exact mix of workshy, cynical and desperate to put you in a position of solving all their problems for them out of sheer exasperation. It's a fairly interesting setup that manages to keep the usual RPG fetch quest formula while also completely justifying it and making sure it never feels like irrelevant busywork.The second half of the game is killing lizardmen in a dungeon crawl.I'm barely exaggerating. Chapters 3 and 4 of the game are spent almost entirely in one dungeon or another, fighting wave after wave of lizardmen. While the early half of the game was fairly restrained in its call to violence, to the point where I don't think I killed more than a dozen humans over the entire course of the game, limiting combat mostly to fending off ill-tempered wildlife, the latter half has you cut down hundreds of lizard men.And to be clear, there's a good reason the combat was so restrained in the first half - Risen's combat is AWFUL. Take Dark Souls, remove the stamina bar, but also take away dodge-rolling, slow block speed to a crawl, and only give the player five armor upgrades over the entire game. I admit with zero shame that I eventually got sick of this and activated godmode at around 2/3rds of the way through Chapter 3. The combat is tolerable in controlled doses, but the second half of the game is almost nothing BUT combat, which the system clearly wasn't designed with in mind.A few more warnings to keep in mind should you try it for yourself:- Don't sell your scrolls, at least not the Telekinesis, Levitation, or Nautilus ones. Despite the ostensible freedom of the RPG mechanics, most of the 'puzzle' mechanics blatantly only have one solution, that being magic. Maybe one in five will give you a problem that can be solved with a bit of athleticism or archery.- Speaking of, don't bother with archery. It doesn't do much damage and the entire group will immediately bumrush you after the first arrow. Additionally, the ranged weapon skills only upgrade draw and reload speed in 10% increments, with no further abilities.- The jump mechanics are quite possibly the absolute worst I've ever seen in a game. In addition to being just really floaty, Risen's edge physics are absolutely terrible. There were roughly a dozen instances where I'd climb up or dump down from a ledge only for the game to be unable to decide whether I'd landed on the ledge or was supposed to slide down, and instead of pushing me down like most games do, it simply left me hovering in the air forever, forcing me to either load a save or restart the program entirely. Unfortunately the game requires you to climb or jump more than a few times to progress, so all I can recommend here is to save often.While the overstuffed combat and the tedium of the second half thoroughly alienated me, I enjoyed the game's opening hours well enough that I'm still going to give Risen 2 a try, but personally I'd say this is one to skip.

												Well guys, as far as an RPG goes this one's a bit messed up. First, lets get the things they've done okay to well noted down: The pace of this game very good but the story is about average, Cliche, but better than some. This is NOT a short 10 hour romp of patheticness that RPGs made now are and the leveling/advancement of your character are at about where you would expect. In addition the world looks amazing especially for when it was made and it doesn't hold your hand as much. NO LOAD SCREENS! Well, Almost none, you WILL be hitting quick load a lot, but I'll get into that later. For the world, story, and looks I'd give this game a 7/10. But, like nearly all seemingly good things this is completely ruined by the following:It commits close to, if not ALL of the unforgivable combat gaming sins:     -all enemies physical attacks are normally twice as fast as yours.     -The game randomly slows your attack to 1/10th your normal speed, giving all enemies      around you free hits as you can't get out of the animation, thus killing you by default through      no fault of your own.     -Your enemies, including wild animals, can parry your parries, but you as a player can't even      with max skills.     -All enemies can attack and hit you instantly, you cannot. Your sword can literally be      connecting with them in your attack and the enemy will often instantly get a super powerfull      atack in that is so fast you can bearly see them move,      doing massive damage to you. You as a player are not capable of this.     -Dodging is of no use as your enemies can track you through it perfectly and hit you anyway. You as a player can't       track or hit, even by chance, a dodging enemy.     -Enemies have unlimited numbers of attacks they can string together while the player, even with the skill that       supposadly allows such, cannot.     -All enemies recover from recoil 3 times faster than you do.     -Enemies sometimes become invulnerable and cannot be harmed, this is also not fixable by reloading a save and       requires the game to be restarted.     -Your character is sometimes spun around by enemy attacks and of course, you are not able to do this to them.     -If you save after you have an enemy's attention any reload of that save will load that enemy within stricking range of      you and attacking, no matter where they were when the original save was created. This renders such save unusable     as you end up dieing the moment the game loads every time, no matter what the cercumstances before the save.     -All enemy melee weapons have greater range than yours no matter what. Enemy has a dagger and you have a two      hand sword? Their dagger out-ranges your sword. Even animals out range your weapons with their horns and teeth.     -Enemy gaurding has a good wide range of defense from the front, But you only have defense for a tiny sliver of angle      that leaves you pulling your hair out as you watch blades swing THROUGH your shield to hit you.So, all in all I'd give non-combat parts of the game a good 7/10. It is a good story and environment but it isn't anything we havent seen before and the story is cliche. But for combat I give it a definate 0/10, that's right, an actual ZERO out of ten. Combat is so buggy and un refined it renders the game completely unplayable a lot of the time and melee combat is based purely on you getting lucky. So unfortunately, I have to give an overall score of 3/10 and can't at all recomend this game to anyone who doesn't want massive levels of frustration.

												Risen is a game of 'let's pretend' for both its developers and devoted fans - let's pretend that it's a hardcore RPG; let's pretend that it's acceptable for a game to be bad until the second act; let's pretend that the combat isn't a chore to sit through. Risen wants to be seen as a no-nonsense "classic" RPG, but all it really does is make the game little more than a chore to sit through. The game starts out with promise, where humanity has forced the Gods from its island, only to face a new and much deadlier threat: the Titans. With the Titans coming to power, powerful storms destroy anything outside of the islands, and mysterious temples rise from the ground to spread fear and, to the adventerous, the urge to explore. Your character is a shipwreck survivor, and a wreck in every other way possible, and is stranded on an island he's never been to before. You're completely neutral from the start, with no intentions of saving the world or conquering it, making it very much like some of my favourite RPGs where you start with no goal. This however doesn't take long to change.From the very start of the game, the combat begins badly and is only worsened over time. At first, sluggish one-two punches and weak waist high kicks are tolerable, but as one acquires weapons, they feel weighty without being visceral. Fighting in this game is nothing like a hardcore RPG, in which you have to know each enemy inside out and strategise before every encounter because, quite frankly, it's impossible. There's absolutely no flow or grace to the combat, instead having clunky dodge mechanics and weird AI, not to mention the animations which make it look bad as well as feel that way. Despite all the moves you can learn with new skills, there's just no variety of moves - it's simple 3-clicks of the left mouse button, and perhaps a bit of moving involved. The worst part about this is that some minor tweaks to the fight engine could've made this significantly better. Instead, I'd sooner avoid fights than risk my sanity for some wolf pelts and raw chicken.Speaking of which, the loot is pathetic. With armour only being available from a few vendors (and so far I've counted 4 pieces of armour in total, two of which are just ordinary clothes), expect to find crummy weapons like sharpened branches, clubs and rusty blades. Don't be disappointed either when you find little gold from the mobs you kill, most of which will be animals anyway, so unless you can find quests where meat and hides are the requirements, you won't get rich quickly, or really at all.But you need to be wealthy in order to make use of your skill points, as with each level up you get 10 skill points to spend on combat and non-combat skills. Seeing as only your health increases when you level up, it's best to spend these points as soon as possible with a clear idea of what you want from them. Oh, and you have to pay the trainer too. Essentially you can learn about 2-3 skills per level, increasing either your stats, combat abilities with certain weapons or learn professions and thievery skills. However by level 10 you'll have learnt the most interesting stuff like pickpocketing (which in fairness is the most useful thing in the game), lockpicking and Alchemy to make potions, so you'll be stuck with saving up to learn how to fight competently.Not that you need to worry about fighting well too much, considering the best time I had in the game (and perhaps this will apply to you; it definitely will when you get into a scrap) was doing fetch quests and talking to people. I'm not one to tolerate MMO-style questing especially in a single player RPG where I want to get away from it all, but when you experience the worst Risen has to offer early on, anything looks better later on. Getting involved in both factions' stories, especially when they escalate in Harbour Town, was far more interesting than whatever's going on with the gods, titans and whatever main story I'm supposed to actually care about.The biggest issue that plagues this game is not its combat, its painfully average writing, its lame voice acting, poor visuals or forgettable - but excellent - sound design; it's the pace. In a nutshell, it takes far too long to get to the decent part of the game, and even then it can be hit or miss. The game requires about five to ten hours, possibly more if it's your first time playing to get to Harbour Town where the two factions can be seen at their best. It's there where you'll find better gear and supplies, plus you'll probably be powerful enough to take on basic to average-level monsters. I don't know about you, but I firmly believe a game should be good the moment I boot it up, not have some potential, and then have to slog through 10+ hours of the most tiring quests I've ever seen to get to what may or may not be better quests.However, the game may appeal to those who can live without quest help and fast travel, for a time. Having to listen to quest dialogue and take notes about important locations or items is as "classic" as this RPG gets, because there's little in the way of map markers or quest pointers; instead you have to rely on the maps you've obtained and find the route to the red dot on it yourself. However if you're a TESIV: Oblivion generation player like myself, this may take some getting used to.I'm not mad because of the lack of modern features which could make the game significantly better; I'm mad because this game wastes too much of the players' time before they so much as feel competent. It's more depressing than disempowering, and for that I cannot recommend Risen. If you need a second opinion, check out my video review below.WARNING: CONTAINS SWEARIES.

r 19, 2015
												I know it's not good to transfer one's initial frustration into a review, but I'm at a complete loss about this game. Either I've grown too old and casual for such games, or there's something wrong about it.Its technically openworldish nature goes in stark contrast with limits and shackles pushed onto you in such a strict manner that it simply feels shocking. Yes, there are no corridors and no narrow passageways between sky-high rocks, but instead you are still separated from your whereabouts by invisible walls of creatures way beyond your level, prices way beyond your possible earnings, and quests way beyond your capabilities - even if you are exactly where you are supposed to be gameplay-wise and story-wise. In RPGs of the kind, I usually act alone in the wilderness, learning stuff, training myself, exploring locations and occasionally going to towns for some quests and business. That gives me the feeling of freedom I need and keeps me comfortably independent from my surroundings. To keep things simple, I'll just say that nothing of this is possible in Risen, and I feel very frustrated about it. One of the most painful limitations for me is the inability to develop the character by means of practice. To learn skills and advance your stats, you must get training from other people. To get training from people, you need money. To get money, you need to fulfill quests. To fulfill quests, you need... to learn skills and advance your stats. I must say, I became tired of running in such circles.Maybe it's all personal, and maybe I'm overestimating some stuff, because I'm going unusually emotional about writing this review, but at the moment I don't feel like I want to continue this game.

												I should've listened to my skepticism, considering this game was made by the same developers that made Gothic series. This game is exactly like the Gothic games, except in slightly better graphics. Tedious menial tasks such as harvesting, collecting, and finding n number of some item are back again. No story hook whatsoever. It's just a random island your character finds himself in after being washed ashore. To add to this, the character's walking speed is very slow and the map isn't detailed enough and shows no landmarks, making exploration a real chore.There are a lot of items to find and the combat is semi-decent, but nothing in this game really stands out. Everything has been done before by other RPGs and done better.Some of the dialogue is not bad and can be kind of witty, but some of the voice acting isn't all that great, especially the main character, who hardly puts any emotion in anything he says, and this is coming from someone who is rarely ever picky about voice acting in games.Some NPC and enemy A.I. is a bit strange too. I got into the arrogant guard captain's house and stole stuff from his treasure chest right in front of him and he did not bust an eyelid. I then took a mug of beer from his table and he got all pissy at me all of a sudden. Another enemy was doing a decent job stopping a few feet away from me, letting me shoot them with a bow, then to chase me for a few steps, and to repeat the same procedure till he was dead.If you liked Gothic games, you'll probably like this one too, but it's way too slow paced for me personally. The most fun I got from this was when I decided to stop doing any quests and to simply mess around. Piranha Bytes just keep rehashing the same old boring formula in every single game, and until they make something new and different, I don't think I'll be buying any more of their games.

content:
18, 2015
												Do you think Skyrim is too good for you? Do you think The Witcher has too many positive attributes for you tastes? Think Dragon Age may be too much on the "enjoyable" side of the spectrum for you liking? Do you prefer poorly designed, unenjoyable games?Oh, you know what the punchline is. But no, actually, this is not a set up to recommend Risen to masochistic people who don't like enjoyability; that would be too generous. This game is one of the most baffling, unexplainably anti-gaming experiences I've ever had. This is the kind of game you use as an indoctrination tool to convince people that gaming is unhealthy. Risen can convince you that games are evil.Now, I haven't spent 18 hours in this game for nothing. I really, really hoped this game would be interesting. Open world RPG gameplay based on exploration, with a sufficiently intriguing main plot but enough diversity to allow you to carve your own paths, is totally up my alley. The plot of this game looked sinister and oblique enough to pique my interesting, the scenery looked pleasant and the musical score sounded beautiful. The positive attributes end there.Right off the bad, you realise this game is every bit as "open world" as Elvis Presley was an octopus. You're presented with plenty of interesting opportunities, but they're all locked off behind unbeatable enemies. The game forces you into the trodden path in the most disappointing way possible: by killing you off instantaneously if you dare to go out of bounds.Before you even get to experience some of the gameplay, you're trampled by the uncaring hooves of the Plot. And therein lies about 90% of the game: walking around and talking to people. You are literally LOCKED inside a town and forced to do lots of talking and lots of walking before you can get to see anything else. You learn here that every action has a consequence: in other words, you're forced to either join one faction or the other. You're led to make some very tough moral decisions; in other words, you do horrible things to horrible people, or you do horrible things to OTHER horrible people. And that's how you're going to spend precious hours of your life and precious dollars (or whatever you local currency is) off your pocket.After that gruelling process, though, you finally get to go outside, and test the skills and the inventory you amassed with great difficulty. What awaits you outside is a battle system that... well, I don't mean to say that it is botched, but... It is botched. Frankly, the combat in this game is one of the most absurd things I've EVER seen in gaming. There's no tactics involved. There's no skills being tested. Nothing. Yes, you have your basic commands (move, attack, defend, etc.) and some extra commands you learn through training (parrying, disarming your enemies, etc.), but the combat ignores that entirely. For starters, EVERY enemy in this game attacks faster than you. And I mean EVERY enemy, including the very first creatures you see. Every time you try to attack, your enemy can attack and hit you instead. This is not something you can just upgrade, no: every single attack in this game boils down to a matter of luck. Also, after being hit, your enemies can INSTANTLY attack you back. There is zero recovery time for your enemies, and stunning them is beyond the game's vocabulary. Also, they can defend themselves indefinitely against any attack. Mostly you can also defend indefinitely, but some stronger enemies can stun you and kill you regardless of defense (this is what makes some of the enemies unbeatable). You think, maybe, that you can defend from your enemy's attack, and use their down time to strike back, but no. They have zero recovery time, remember? You think maybe you can dodge them instead, but no. That doesn't work either. Fighting in this game boils down to a single process: first, you defend. Then, you let go of your defense, and HOPE the enemy doesn't attack you. Then, you attack, and HOPE the attack lands. Then, you immediately defend. If you're feeling adventurous, you can try a second, stronger attack, but again, you have to hope. Finally, you defend again. Repeat. THIS is the combat. We're not talking about difficulty here. We're not talking about combat that is designed to be hard, after all, to insinuate this system was "designed" is an insult to the art of game design to begin with. We're talking about a combat system made by people who never played a decent game in their life. To be successful in a one-to-one battle consists of saving and loading the game over and over. It's a matter of patience, but at least it's doable, you know, it's playable. For that reason, most of the time, the game pits you against three or four enemies simultaneously.Now here is where the whole thing utterly falls apart. Fighting more than one enemy multiplies all of the problems. ALL the enemies are entirely transparent to each other's attacks; you can get hit by an enemy striking THROUGH another enemy standing between you and it. As long as you're holding the defense button, the character will "lock" onto the enemy in front of you, but an enemy standing slightly to the side can strike and hit you; but to lock onto a different enemy, you have to move your mouse SO far that you'll need three or four additional desks around you. Often, the character will be defending an enemy that is standing yards away from you, while one that's right next to you will successfully hit you, only because you were too slow dragging your mouse all the way to the Moon so you could lock onto him. Again, not only the enemy you're locked to can successfully hit you even if they attack you AFTER you started your own attacks, the other enemies around you can hit you as well, so the luck factor is multiplied. EVERY fight in this game is decided entirely by the random number generator and by saving/loading.You think that you can tilt the odds in your favour by gaining levels and improving your inventory. Theoretically yes, but then we bump into another problem: the game is EXTRAORDINARILY STINGY. Deafeating even the hardest enemies will give you negligible experience boosts. Most of the levelling up you'll get from this game will be completing quests, which as has been said, boils down mostly to walking and talking. You'll get more experience talking than fighting. The same is true for money: the enemy drops are entirely worthless, as well as most items you find. And don't think that you can haggle for prices or look for better merchants: everyone pays exactly the same prices for everything. And trust me, you'll need money. The levels you get give you learning points, which must be invested in the skills you want by training with people. To train, you need to spend money, and it ain't cheap. But don't think you can just spend your hard earned money in the skills you so desperately need, no: in this game, many of the obligatory quests can ONLY be completed by spending money. But even if you do improve your skills, this does not mitigate the luck factor from the battles; it will just make them last a little shorter.All of that just to reach some new area and advance the plot. Eventually the fights started to become entirely unavoidable, endless, repetitive, and of course, entirely luck based. I was playing just to justify the money I spent on it, but even that was becoming too gruesome. I was needlessly torturing myself for a game that wasn't worth it. Why should I play this instead of, say, The Witcher? Or Dragon Age? Or just Skyrim again? There's no point. There are many, many more things that are awfully botched in this game, but this review would go on forever. No wonder this game is so cheap and always on sale, but don't be fooled by it. Save your money and your time for a good game.18 hours...

												Where do I start with a game like this?I guess the first thing to do is denounce any notion that this is an open-world game. After you break out of the linear tutorial, you can't exactly go out and do your own thing. High-level monsters litter all but a select few paths, and the only way to figure out whether or not you can pass is to fight these monsters (and surely get your ♥♥♥ kicked).So, of the few paths you can take, you'll end up in one town or another, with different factions, altough really, they're all the same: masculine-looking people who hate you. Almost EVERY person you meet is a total ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥. I understand wanting to have a game where you're not instantly likeable, but this is way beyond that. I guess I understand it, though, since a thumbtack has more personality than whoever the hell you play as. He's boring, he's constantly finding ways to ♥♥♥♥ people off, and his voice acting is poorly-delivered.Shaping and growing your one-dimensional protagist is no fun either. EVERYTHING in this game can kick your ♥♥♥. No matter how decent the combat is, if you end up fighting a group of more than two enemies, even if they're weaker, you're screwed. And for how good the combat is, you can't easily heal during battle, so if you don't land your blows right away, you're dead. If you wander off into the woods and into a pack of wolves, they'll chase you and kill you.So, that limits your area of fun to the towns. Not only do people hate you and constantly crap on you, but the few quests you can actually figure out how to get are your simple MMO "get me 50 of something" or "go here and kill this thing" quests. Not to mention there are no landmarks, waypoints, or any other mechanics to help you find the places these people want you to go. Why should I bother finding these quest locations if I'm just gonna get wrecked by a camp of gnomes or a wolf that happened to be guarding the tracks?So, you can't do quests. Maybe you can go out adventuring on your own somewhere? Hah! Your character is about as devoid of adventuring skills as you are. You know nothing when you begin, and it's not readily apparent *how* you learn skills. When I tell my character to use a chest, he looks at it and goes, "Wish I knew how to pick locks." When I try to use a cauldron, he goes "I don't know how to use that." When I try to use an anvil or a grindstone he goes "I'm not a smith."So, you can't do anything in this game. Quests are boring, and even when you try to take them on you're greeted with either failure and defeat or the opportunity to get chewed out by complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥ delivering very bad dialogue. I've put about 5 hours into this game and I don't know how to improve my skills. So I'm stuck in an endless cycle of disappointment. This game isn't even fun in the "it kicks your ♥♥♥" kind of way. It's not fun in any way. Sure, the graphics are pretty and the music is excellent, but really, that does nothing to save this game. Risen is terrible. Don't waste your money.

												Foremost a caveat: This review is highly subjective and doesn't analyze flaws in the combat rules or the character levelling system as some other very detailed reviews do it. I may have given up too early and haven't seen much of the game. Maybe I will revisit it eventually, but my own experience hasn't been good. It could be due to a non-matching personal taste.Compared to my first impressions with the awesome games "Gothic II: Gold Edition" and "Gothic", during the first few hours I've tried out "Risen", I've felt turned off due to various factors.The graphics are more complex than in the Gothic games. Okay. For example, there is deep underwood you can move through in some places, but which blocks your view completely. It complicates exploration, and often you bump into impassable vegetation or rocks directly behind a section where you could move through. And no way to climb up or explore more freely.Everything is too colorful and cartoonish. Giant moths? Urgh! Worst of all, the player and NPC animations during conversation and movement are very clunky. Hard to imagine that I would want to move around (and fight!) with such clunky animations for a long time. I cannot enjoy the silly gestures during conversation. It's like watching a movie with bad actors.The open world feeling has been severely restricted already near the starting location,  forcing you to follow one narrow and almost safe path leading to NPCs that don't manage to raise your interest. Not with what they do and not with what they tell you. Shrug. The linear story forces you to talk to them about some bits only and staying vague. Just a few steps into the swamp, powerful enemies lurk. So near to those NPCs. It doesn't matter to me that some highly experienced players of Risen may be able to kill them early in half an hour or a longer battle. You are not expected to do that at that point. Just as in the Gothic games, you don't know how strong an enemy is and what it takes to defeat it. Or you try to explore more of the limited paths and stumble into a cave or another dungeon that is not for you yet. Yeah, understood, avoid those places and return to errand boy duties.So, another game where you build up meta-gaming knowledge by trial and error, save and reload, again and again. The next time you know where to go, when to do it, how long to save skills points and when to spend them on which skills. Early on I could kill a couple of early wolves, sting rats, giant moths and huge birds with the help of a shield I found, and with considerable effort trying to do damage to them while blocking their attacks, but combat already seemed very repetitive and tedious. I guess I'm supposed to ignore combat for an unknown time and gain experience points with non-combat tasks, and yet one early task involves fighting some nasty worm.To me it seems it might be possible to have some fun with Risen, if one can live with the clunky animations and combat mechanics and build up enough meta-gaming knowledge to know where to go first. If only the story managed to pull you in. It hasn't done that for me.

content:
14, 2013
RISENA fairly shallow and flawed third-person action RPG.Rating 4/10Risen came out in 2009 around the same time as Dragon Age and in comparison it looks and plays like a game that should have been released in 2003. For an RPG it gets a lot of the basics wrong, there is very little in the way of character creation or character choice. You play an uninteresting potato head looking protagonist with no back-story or motivations other than you've been ship wrecked on an island in an unknown world. There are three different ways of playing your character, as a mage, warrior or hunter. You are able to level up various skills such as strength or sword fighting through training that can be purchased from various NPCs around the island. It's incredibly simplistic and offers no real choice.The NPCs littered around the island in small limited number of locations are lifeless and bland. The voice actors sound as though they have no interest and everything is delivered monotone which is strange considering the vast talent they've arranged for the voice actors such as Andy Serkis and Lena Headey. It also doesn't help that the character models look awful like they've come from a game made in the early 2000s. I struggle to think of a single interesting character in the game and even the characters with some promise like Patty have woeful looking models which undermine the character. Combat is a clunky and frustrating experience, based on timing and luck. Enemies enter into attack cycles, you have to block until they've finished their cycle and it turns into a repetitive and boring game of waiting. When there are three or more enemies it becomes quite hard as every hit you take breaks your current attack and being hit from all sides gives you very little option other than running away. Whilst combat becomes easier as the game progresses it still remains an incredibly frustrating experience.The menu and item system seem to have been an after thought. There is no limit on how much you can carry, at all, meaning I was running around carrying 500 heavy weapons. With no inventory limits it means you give little thought to what you loot as you can take everything. More often than not I just spammed the loot button on enemy bodies without bothering to check what they had. Added to this the serious lack of weapons and armour, I came across 4 sets of armour during the game and you don't get the first set of armour until at least 7 or 8 hours into the game. There is also no reason for half the items you pick up, food and frying pans are all meaningless after the first few hours. All you need are potions are spells and the small number of items needed to make them.There are some positives, the environment looks pretty good with a great Island setting and the story moves along a fairly quick pace with a couple of great side quests. However it's not enough to make up for all the games flaws which outweigh what little good there is.

content:
r 31, 2013
												Risen is an RPG that continues to follows the same theme as the Gothic series. The story is generic high fantasy with forgettable characters with even more forgettable quest and storyline. Like most of Piranha Byte's work in this genre, the combat is abysmally bad. Risen would've been at the very least acceptable if it wasn't such an unnecessarily long winded and bug ridden game. Risen is chock full of bugs, many of which will break quest line. I personally couldn't finish this game without the use of console commands to fix certain quests. The game becomes an absolute cluster poop once you hit the volcano mid game as important quest npc's get stuck or the lever that was suppose to open gates stopped working. Console commands can fix some of these issues, but the customer shouldn't have to resort to cheats to proceed in a video game.I can only think of one other RPG with combat that is even worse than Risen and that is Gothic 1. Coincidentally that was also made by Piranha Bytes. The combat in Risen is reliant on a very bad target locking system; it locks on the closest target, and you cannot change targets manually. This means that if a enemies groups up on you, you are going to be swinging at the air as the bull poop lock-on system wildly changes targets automatically. You will then proceed to die as enemies stun-lock you in to oblivion.The game store page indicates that this game is 60 hours of game play, which is mostly correct if you consider that 40 of those hours are spent wandering aimlessly to find the next place to turn in your quest. The directions in the dialogue are outright terrible and the lack luster quest marker made the questing even more tedious and boring. Now compound that with the fact that Risen is comprised of mostly fetch quests and you have a recipe for one of the most boring RPG experience ever. Risen is basically Dark Souls with none of the awesome or the refinement in game-play.
